I would also like to congratulate you on this paper! Very interesting
indee=
d! I have a few questions and comments as well:

1) Network activation: I t=
hink there are two ways of updating the states of
the neurons: (i) synchron=
ous and (ii) asynchronous.

The asynchronous update is basically what is do=
ne in networks with layers,
where a signal starting at the input layer at t=
ime t arrives at the output
layer at the same timestep. The synchronous upd=
ate is what most people
implement in networks with a free topology, where t=
he neuron inputs at time
t produce the output at time t+1. This delay can b=
e interpreted as the time
for a signal to be propagated from a presynaptic =
neuron to a postsynaptic
one. Consequently, in order to express causality o=
f firing, in the hebbian
rule the presynaptic activity should be taken from=
 time t-1, while the
postsynaptic activity should be taken from time t.

I =
was wondering whether you experimented with this. In your paper you say
tha=
t the network is activated 15 times, so are you using the synchronous
state=
 update?

2) Have you experimented with learning rules other than the stand=
ard
Hebbian one? For example, the rules of the original Adaptive HyperNEAT
=
paper, or by adding a weight decay to the equation of the standard Hebbian
=
rule.

3) I was wondering whether you thought of any other tasks to evaluat=
e your
approach. For example, line orientation maps develop in the primary =
visual
cortex, and as you say in the paper, these topographic maps are foun=
d in
all sensory systems. So, would it be sensible to have a task in which =
you
"use" other feature detector cells, let's say from the primary auditory=

cortex, and a topographic map is then self-organized to encode sound
frequ=
encies?

4) I believe line orientation maps exist at the lowest level of a
=
hierarchical architecture, and as information moves to higher levels, more
=
abstract concepts can be encoded. These abstract concepts can fuse
informat=
ion from all sensory systems, e.g., how does a dog looks like,
smells like,=
 sounds like, etc. I believe that using HyperNEAT with such
hierarchical ar=
chitectures (and not just for developing a controller) is a
promising appro=
ach and I look forward to seeing it mature.


Vassilis


On Mon, Apr 28, 20=
14 at 12:47 PM, Sebastian Risi
<sebastian.risi@...>wrote:

>
>
> Kenn=
eth Stanley and I are pleased to announce our new GECCO paper (to
> appear)=
, "Guided Self-Organization in Indirectly Encoded and Evolving
> Topographi=
c Maps"
>
> *PDF: *http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf
>
> This=
 paper introduces the idea that HyperNEAT can be seeded with a lateral
> in=
hibitory connectivity pattern, which then allows the weights from the
> inp=
uts to the hidden layer of an ANN to self-organize to form a genuine
> topo=
graphic map of the input space. The benefit of this new approach is
> that =
the initial seed can be evolved further to accelerate the
> self-organizing=
 process and to bias it towards a specific target
> configuration. An inter=
esting implication is that enabling HyperNEAT to
> capture this key feature=
 of natural systems might now allow us to evolve
> architectures resembling=
 deep learning networks, SOMs, or other
> self-organizing processes that al=
so rely on unsupervised learning processes.
>
> *Abstract: *An important ph=
enomenon seen in many areas of biological
> brains and recently in deep lea=
rning architectures is a process known as
> self-organization. For example,=
 in the primary visual cortex, color and
> orientation maps develop based o=
n lateral inhibitory connectivity patterns
> and Hebbian learning dynamics.=
 These topographic maps, which are found in
> all sensory systems, are thou=
ght to be a key factor in enabling abstract
> cognitive representations. Th=
is paper shows for the first time that the
> Hypercube-based NeuroEvolution=
 of Augmenting Topologies (HyperNEAT) method
> can be seeded to begin evolu=
tion  with such lateral connectivity, enabling
> genuine self-organizing dy=
namics. The proposed approach draws on
> HyperNEAT's ability to generate a =
pattern of weights across the
> connectivity of an artificial neural networ=
k (ANN) based on a function of
> its geometry. Validating this approach, th=
e afferent weights of an ANN
> self-organize in this paper to form a genuin=
e topographic map of the input
> space for a simple line orientation task. =
Most interestingly, this seed can
> then be evolved further, providing a me=
thod to guide the self-organization
> of weights in a specific way, much as=
 evolution likely guided the
> self-organizing trajectories of biological b=
rains.
>
> Cheers,
> Sebastian
>
> --
> Dr. Sebastian Risi
> Assistant Prof=
essor

> Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 230=
0 Copenhagen, Denmark

risi.com

>

<div dir=3D"ltr"><div>I would also like to congratulate you on this paper! =
Very interesting indeed! I have a few questions and comments as well:</div>=
<div><br></div><div>1) Network activation: I think there are two ways of up=
dating the states of the neurons: (i) synchronous and (ii) asynchronous.=C2=
=A0</div>
<div><br></div><div>The asynchronous update is basically what is =
done in networks with layers, where a signal starting at the input layer at=
 time t arrives at the output layer at the same timestep. The synchronous u=
pdate is what most people implement in networks with a free topology, where=
 the neuron inputs at time t produce the output at time t+1. This delay can=
 be interpreted as the time for a signal to be propagated from a presynapti=
c neuron to a postsynaptic one. Consequently, in order to express causality=
 of firing, in the hebbian rule the presynaptic activity should be taken fr=
om time t-1, while the postsynaptic activity should be taken from time t.</=
div>
<div><br></div><div>I was wondering whether you experimented with this=
. In your paper you say that the network is activated 15 times, so are you =
using the synchronous state update?</div><div><br></div><div>2) Have you ex=
perimented with learning rules other than the standard Hebbian one? For exa=
mple, the rules of the original Adaptive HyperNEAT paper, or by adding a we=
ight decay to the equation of the standard Hebbian rule.</div>
<div><br></d=
iv><div>3) I was wondering whether you thought of any other tasks to evalua=
te your approach. For example, line orientation maps develop in the primary=
 visual cortex, and as you say in the paper, these topographic maps are fou=
nd in all sensory systems. So, would it be sensible to have a task in which=
 you "use" other feature detector cells, let's say from the p=
rimary auditory cortex, and a topographic map is then self-organized to enc=
ode sound frequencies?</div>
<div><br></div><div>4) I believe line orientat=
ion maps exist at the lowest level of a hierarchical architecture, and as i=
nformation moves to higher levels, more abstract concepts can be encoded. T=
hese abstract concepts can fuse information from all sensory systems, e.g.,=
 how does a dog looks like, smells like, sounds like, etc. I believe that u=
sing HyperNEAT with such hierarchical architectures (and not just for devel=
oping a controller) is a promising approach and I look forward to seeing it=
 mature.</div>
<div><br></div><div><br></div><div>Vassilis</div></div><div =

p></p><div dir=3D"ltr">Kenneth Stanley and I are pleased to announce our ne=
w GECCO paper (to appear), "Guided Self-Organization in Indirectly Enc=
oded and Evolving Topographic Maps"<br><br><b>PDF: </b><a href=3D"http=
://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf" target=3D"_blank">http://eplex=
.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco14.pdf</a><br>

<br>This paper introduces the =
idea that HyperNEAT can be seeded with a lateral inhibitory connectivity pa=
ttern, which then allows the weights from the inputs to the hidden layer=C2=
=A0of an ANN to self-organize to form a genuine topographic map of the inpu=
t=C2=A0space. The benefit of this new approach is that the initial seed can=
=C2=A0be evolved further to accelerate the self-organizing process and to=
=C2=A0bias it towards a specific target configuration. An interesting impli=
cation=C2=A0is that enabling HyperNEAT to capture this key feature of=C2=A0=
natural systems might now allow us to evolve architectures resembling=C2=A0=
deep learning networks, SOMs, or other self-organizing processes that also =
rely on unsupervised learning processes.<br>

<br><b>Abstract: </b>An impor=
tant phenomenon seen in many areas of biological brains and recently in dee=
p learning architectures is a process known as self-organization. For examp=
le, in the primary visual cortex, color and orientation maps develop based =
on lateral inhibitory connectivity patterns and Hebbian learning dynamics. =
These topographic maps, which are found in all sensory systems, are thought=
 to be a key factor in enabling abstract cognitive representations. This pa=
per shows for the first time that the Hypercube-based NeuroEvolution of Aug=
menting Topologies (HyperNEAT) method can be seeded to begin evolution =C2=
=A0with such lateral connectivity, enabling genuine self-organizing dynamic=
s. The proposed approach draws on HyperNEAT's ability to generate a pat=
tern of weights across the connectivity of an artificial neural network (AN=
N) based on a function of its geometry. Validating this approach, the affer=
ent weights of an ANN self-organize in this paper to form a genuine topogra=
phic map of the input space for a simple line orientation task. Most intere=
stingly, this seed can then be evolved further, providing a method to guide=
 the self-organization of weights in a specific way, much as evolution like=
ly guided the self-organizing trajectories of biological brains.<br>

<br>C=
heers,<br>Sebastian<br><br>--<br>Dr. Sebastian Risi<br>Assistant Professor =
<br>IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08<br>Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 C=
openhagen, Denmark<br>email: <a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." ta=
rget=3D"_blank">sebastian.risi@...</a>, web: <a href=3D"http://www.se=
bastianrisi.com" target=3D"_blank">www.sebastianrisi.com</a><br>

target=3D"_blank">+45-7218-5127</a>
